Award.AwardTitle: ABI Sustaining: eBird: Maintaining the Cyberinfrastructure to Support the Collection, Storage, Archive, Analysis, and Access to a Global Biodiversity Data Resource
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cornell University is awarded a grant to support the continued exponential growth of eBird, an online data resource for global bird biodiversity. With its launch in 2002, eBird opened a new era of live, online checklisting for birders, and it soon became one of the world's largest citizen-science projects. By 2012, eBird had amassed 100 million total bird observations, and early in 2014 that number is 170 million-on track to double the previous decade's worth of data in just 2 years. With more than 200,000 citizen-science participants worldwide, eBird acts as a global-scale, real-time bird monitoring mechanism that is innovating new models of conservation. For example, a first-of-its-kind conservation project in California is using eBird models to target the flooding of rice fields in the specific places, and at precisely the right times, for waterfowl and shorebirds during migration. eBird's openly available data has been downloaded by more than 6,000 students, educators, government staff, and researchers, resulting in more than 110 peer-reviewed scientific papers. True to its beginnings, eBird is still grounded in serving as an essential tool for birding. More than 7 million people access eBird every year to explore data through interactive exploration, visualization and analysis tools that help birders find more birds.


Much of the research in basic and applied ecology is founded in descriptions of distribution and abundance of species. Long-term, well-organized data covering broad spatial scales are necessary for documenting change, generating hypotheses for their causes, and ultimately understanding how these changes relate to overall ecosystem health and function. While collecting a single-species occurrence datum is a well-understood process, the coordinated collection, curation, access, and storage of these data is no small task. Appropriately structured and sustained, the cyberinfrastructure that supports large species occurrence datasets can add value to the data, instead of merely acting as a tool for aggregating observations. The eBird data management infrastructure provides a unique resource for students, scientists, land managers, governments and amateurs. eBird's data: (1) come from a single, consistently gathered and curated source that is openly available and widely in use, (2) represents a substantial proportion of all available data on distribution of all organisms globally, and (3) provides these data in not just minimal form but as a set of value-added products that lower the threshold of data management needed to use these data. For more information about eBird, visit its website at http://ebird.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A foundation for research in basic and applied ecology and conservation science is data on the distribution and abundance of species. Long-term, well-organized data covering broad spatial and temporal scales at high spatial and temporal resolution is imperative for documenting change, generating hypothesis for their causes, and ultimately taking conservation action to maintain overall ecosystem health and function. While collecting a single species occurrence datum is a well-understood process, the coordinated collection, curation, access and storage of these data at scale is not a trivial task. Over the past 5 years this ABI Sustaining award has assisted the Cornell Lab of Ornithology in maintaining the cyberinfrastructure to support the collection, storage, access, and analysis of eBird—one of the largest and fastest growing species monitoring projects in existence. During these 5 years eBird data sets and data products have provided enormous value to a large, diverse, and growing community of academic researchers, students, NGO/governmental, commercial, and the general public.

The eBird enterprise is a cooperative partnership between birders who submit their observations to a central database and a diverse group of experts in a wide range of fields: ornithologists, conservation biologists, quantitative ecologists, statisticians, computer scientists, GIS and informatics specialists, application developers, and data administrators. Instead of merely acting as a tool for collecting and aggregating observations, eBird actively disseminates data and provides tools and training to help manipulate and analyze these data. Finally, identifying the need for, and creating, value-added products from the data ensure broad usage, and more than 4 million individuals, from every country, have visited the eBird website over the past 12 months. The integration of eBird data — extending from contributors to users — is a unique strength of the eBird Enterprise providing benefits to a diverse and global user community.

Broader impacts: A fundamental principle of eBird is to provide free and open access to data for a broad spectrum of data consumers. The eBird cyberinfrastructure has been designed to facilitate this and provide data in multiple forms. Additionally, eBird provides software tools and training to allow users with minimal computer resources the opportunity to access, query, and analyze eBird data. The eBird enterprise expands the capacity to explore biological research questions from diverse career backgrounds and perspectives—engaging the general public, students and educators, researchers and government agencies throughout the scientific process. 

Intellectual merits: The processes that affect the distributions of animals and plants operate at multiple spatial and temporal scales, presenting a unique challenge for the development and coordination of effective conservation strategies, particularly for wide-ranging species. eBird is assembling one of the largest and fastest growing resources of biodiversity data and making these data openly available. Started in 2002, eBird has collected more than 730 million bird observations from 500 thousand contributors globally. The project is growing exponentially and we anticipate gathering almost 120 million observations in 2019. The eBird enterprise has made significant advances in providing access to a global data resource of bird occurrences and the tools to study them that are now providing new insights in ecological systems at appropriate scales. The result has been the number of studies that cite eBird has grown exponentially. The Web of Science identifies a total of 159 peer-reviewed scientific studies, starting with one publication in 2008 and ending with 37 in 2019.  The fields represented by these publications encompasses 50 Web of Science categories, with the majority occurring in ecology or related fields.
